text: Our daughter will have very rageful tantrums that will last up to half an hour, with absolutely no way to pacify her.
A few days ago, he started hitting when I would take something away from him that he wanted.
I'm talking screaming, throwing herself in the sand and doing her best crocodile death roll impression.
I have a 2.5 year old daughter who's been going through an emotional roller coaster the last couple of months.
If my daughter doesn't get her way it leads to major meltdowns.
I am at the end of my tether and don't know how to manage my 26month old boy. He is a nightmare! From the minute he wakes up everything is a challenge. He screams, kicks, hits us and sister.
Sometimes his tantrums start because of a clearly identified reason, like he can't have something that he wants. But it seems like most of the time, they come out of nowhere.
Screaming not eating
This means it's very difficult to pick her up so I just sit on the ground trying my best to cradle her head in my lap while she freaks out so she doesn't hurt herself.
It spirals downward from there. He starts throwing things, repeatedly yelling "No!".
He was like an alligator on meth, flailing, death rolling, and screaming.
So whenever something sets her off she's a literal drama queen.

Most of the time the things she's asking for are things that we would have no problem giving her if she just asked for them. But she jumps straight into meltdown mode, and we can't really give her what she wants when she's acting like that.
To deal with her emotions a little better
At their worst, he clinches his fists and grits his teeth and shakes and has a look of sheer rage on his face.
Anger management
My 2.5 year old gets agitated regularly and now he has dropped his nap (he's not really ready) he gets more tired and arsey as the day goes on!!
I notice that he does it when he is angry/overwhelmed and I wish I had something to distract him when this happens.
I hope to help her understand her emotions and find ways to cope without lashing out as hitting and not listening are a major problem for us

Now, seemingly out of nowhere, she will decide that she "needs" something. So she will go straight to full tantrum meltdown mode and start screaming "I NEED <insert thing here>!!!!" Over and over and over, while crying, hitting furniture, growling, and trying to breathe.

So this morning he’s screaming hysterically to then go downstairs, obviously I don’t know if I’ve done the right thing to ignore him and not arise to his behaviour but then I can see it’s infuriating him a two year old screaming on top of his lungs, then starts hitting, scramming me even hitting me to the face.
By 'tantrum' I mean, one thing gets her going and then 15 minutes later she's rolling on the ground and screaming like she needs in exorcism.
twelve month old who has incredibly aggressive, prolonged tantrums, up to ten/twelve times a day
It was the end of my son's bath (he likes baths), so I took him out of the tub and brought him into his room, where he proceed to have a meltdown.
Or if it’s really bad because he is tired, I just put him down for a nap.
Every single fucking thing is a power struggle.
Mostly my son is delightful (!). He's happy, sociable, chatty etc etc. And pretty compliant.
For example this evening, I asked him to shut the door quietly. He said he was going to slam it. I said no you're not. And he then deliberately slammed it twice.
He plays us against each other which creates strife between my husband and I.
When she throws fits to get what she wants I tell her what she can have and ignore her until she calms down.
The most frequent cause is not getting the snack she wants (ex. She wants a cookie I offer grapes.)
If Daddy gives a bath, he will whine and cry for Mommy to wash him.
